feature.name: daily wage calculator
feature.description: The daily wage calculator is a payroll system feature that automatically computes and deducts daily pay for employees taking unpaid leave. It calculates the appropriate salary reduction by dividing the employee's total salary (basic plus allowance) by the number of actual working days in the month. The system accounts for public holidays by subtracting them from the total working days, and supports both calendar day and working day leave policies. Once an unpaid leave request is approved, the calculator automatically generates the corresponding pay deduction and reflects it on the payroll table.

source_articles_index.title: How is daily pay calculated
source_articles_index.article_summary: Explains how daily pay is calculated for unpaid leave deductions. Defines the formula as Daily Pay = Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Number of actual working days in the month. Describes how public holidays are deducted from working days to calculate actual working days. Distinguishes between calendar days and working days leave policies. Provides an example showing how 2 public holidays reduce 22 working days to 20 actual working days for calculation purposes. Details that automatic pay deductions are created and reflected on the payroll table upon unpaid leave approval.

source_articles_index.title: Introduction to daily wage calculator
source_articles_index.article_summary: Introduces the Daily Wage Calculator feature as a flexible alternative to previous limited daily wage calculation methods. Explains three calculation bases (calendar days, working days, custom days), salary component selection options, access location (Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation), and impact on salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction. Identifies authorized user roles (Superadmin, Payroll table managers, transaction processors) and provides definitions of each calculation base with emphasis on UAE/KSA labor law compliance.

source_articles_index.title: Salary Proration
source_articles_index.article_summary: Explains how Super admins can configure salary proration in the Daily Wage Calculator by selecting calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days). Documents the navigation path (Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation), the save process, and critical constraint that changes affect all active unpaid payroll amounts. Includes guidance on managing prorated salary transactions when payroll month is open, requiring transaction rejection before saving new proration settings.

procedures.procedure_name: Calculate Daily Pay for Unpaid Leave
procedures.when_to_use: When an unpaid leave request has been approved and needs to be reflected as a salary deduction
steps: Receive and approve unpaid leave request
Determine the employee's leave policy type (calendar days or working days)
Identify the total number of days in the policy for the month (e.g., 22 working days or 30 calendar days)
Identify all public holidays falling in the month
Subtract public holidays from the total working days to calculate actual working days
Calculate daily pay using formula: Daily Pay = Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Actual Working Days
System automatically generates and reflects the pay deduction on the payroll table

procedures.when_to_use: When setting up payroll system or updating daily wage calculation methodology to align with company policies or labor law requirements.
steps: Select calculation base (calendar days, working days, or custom days)
Choose salary components to include (basic salary, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only)
Apply configuration to impact salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction calculations

procedures.when_to_use: When organization needs to change how employee salaries are prorated based on days worked, or when adjusting calculation methodology for payroll accuracy.
steps: Navigate to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation
Select the required calculation basis (custom days, calendar days, or working days)
If payroll month is open with existing prorated salary transactions, reject those transactions before saving new proration settings
Confirm new proration settings are applied to all active unpaid payroll amounts

rules_limitations_constraints.rule: Daily pay formula is: Daily Pay = Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Number of actual working days in the month ; The number of days used in calculation depends on the leave policy: either calendar days (e.g., 30 days) or working days (e.g., 22 working days) ; Public holidays falling in the month must be deducted from the working days to arrive at the actual working days used in the daily pay calculation ; Only approved unpaid leave requests trigger automatic pay deduction creation

Calendar days calculation uses actual month length: January has 31 days, February has 28 days (or 29 in leap years), and other months vary accordingly. ; Working days calculation excludes weekends and public holidays as defined in the company's public holiday calendar; only business days are counted. ; Custom days calculation allows payroll managers to set a fixed number of days per month according to company policies; most UAE and KSA companies set custom days to 30 to comply with local labor law.

Changes to salary proration settings affect all active (unpaid) amounts in the payroll table immediately upon save. When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions have been submitted for one or multiple employees, Super admin must reject those transactions before saving new salary proration changes.

edge_cases_warnings.edge_case_or_warning: When public holidays coincide with the month being calculated, they must be subtracted from the working days count. For example, if 2 days are public holidays in a month with 22 working days, daily pay is calculated using 20 days instead of 22 ; The leave policy type (calendar days vs. working days) significantly impacts the daily pay calculation and must be correctly identified before calculation

Monthly day count variations affect daily wage calculations: months with different numbers of days (28, 30, or 31) will produce different daily rates when using calendar days calculation base. ; Selection of different calculation bases (calendar days vs. working days vs. custom days) and different salary components can significantly impact final wage calculations for salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction.

When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions are already submitted for employees, Super admin cannot simply save new proration settings; must first reject existing prorated salary transactions, then save the new proration configuration to avoid transaction conflicts.

Daily Wage Calculator directly impacts three payroll processes: salary proration calculations, leave encashment calculations, and unpaid leave deduction calculations. ; Depends on company public holiday calendar configuration to accurately determine working days when working days calculation base is selected.
Daily Wage Calculator interacts with the Payroll system and directly impacts active payroll table transactions, employee first salary calculations, and end-of-service settlement amounts.
